TAIWAN TRAVEL ACT; NORTH KOREAN HUMAN RIGHTS REAUTHORIZATION ACT OF 2017; AND DISTRIBUTION AND PROMOTION OF RIGHTS AND KNOWLEDGE ACT OF 2017</Doc-title> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="">THURSDAY, JUNE 15, 2017</paragraph> <option>Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific,</option> <option> Committee on Foreign Affairs, Washington, DC. The subcommittee met, pursuant to notice, at 2:30 p.m., in room 2200 Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Ted Yoho (chairman of the subcommittee) presiding. Mr. Yoho. The subcommittee will come to order. Good afternoon. We have called this markup to order today to consider four important measures that touch on pressing challenges that the United States faces in the Asia-Pacific region. After the conclusion of this brief business meeting, we will proceed immediately to our scheduled hearing on U.S.- Taiwan ties. Pursuant to notice, we have four bipartisan measures on our agenda this afternoon. As members were notified yesterday, it is the intention of the Chair to consider today's business en bloc so that we can proceed promptly to our hearing. All members may have 5 days to insert remarks into the record and, without objection, the following measures and amendments will be considered en bloc: House Resolution 311, reaffirming 40 years of relations between the United States and the Association of the Southeast Asian Nations; Yoho Amendment 37 in the Nature of a Substitute to H. Resolution 311; H.R. 535, the Taiwan Travel Act; H.R. 2061, the North Korean Human Rights Reauthorization Act of 2017; Yoho Amendment 38 to H.R. 2061; and H.R. 2397, the Distribution and Promotion of Rights and Knowledge of DPRK Act of 2017. Before turning to our ranking member, I recognize myself to speak on--and the Connolly Amendment--excuse me--Amendment 26 to H.R. 2061. And thank you. </option>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>[The information referred to follows:]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker=""> House of Representatives, </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Yoho">First, we have House Resolution 311, which recognizes 40 years of the U.S.-ASEAN ties and reaffirms the economic security interests we share with this dynamic group of countries.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Yoho">I want to thank Representatives Wagner and Castro, who chair the recently revived ASEAN Caucus. We are offering this measure for focusing on an area that is sometimes overlooked but very much deserving of our attention. The 10 nations of ASEAN have tremendous potential for growth and share our interests in a secure bipolar Asia. So, reaffirming our relations is an important undertaking.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Yoho">We will also consider the Taiwan Travel Act authored by Mr. Chabot, the chairman emeritus of the subcommittee. Chairman Chabot's bill will strengthen U.S.-Taiwan relations by codifying a policy of greater freedom of movement for the Republic of China officials in the United States and will also facilitate more high-level interactions between our governments.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Yoho">In the face of China's intensifying efforts to restrict Taiwan's international space, strengthening our relationships with Taiwan is especially important. So I thank Chairman Chabot for introducing this measure.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Next, we consider Chairman Ros-Lehtinen's reauthorization of the North Korea Human Rights Act, as the 2014 U.N. Commission of Inquiry of North Korea found the gravity, scale, and nature of human rights abuses reveals a state that does not have any parallel in the contemporary world. Indeed, the Kim regime is the world's worst human rights abuser and North Korea Human Rights Act is a fundamental part of congressional leadership to end these abuses.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Yoho">I have offered a technical amendment to this legislation to unify some of its authorization with legislation the committee has passed since the Human Rights Act was last reauthorized and look forward to sending this bill to the full committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Finally, we consider the Distribution and Promotion of Rights and Knowledge Act of 2017. This bill will promote the freedom of information and democracy in North Korea and I would like to thank the ranking member, Mr. Sherman, as well as Chairman Royce, and Ranking Member Engel of the full committee for joining us as original cosponsors on this legislation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Yoho">This bill will expand the authority of the President and the Broadcasting Board of Governors to transmit and distribute information inside North Korea, one of the surest ways to weaken the Kim regime's grip on power, to promote freedom and liberties.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Yoho">My sincere thanks to my colleagues for joining us today to move these important measures further along in the legislative process.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Yoho"> I now recognize our ranking member, Mr. Sherman, for any remarks he may have. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Sherman">We have four excellent bills. We should pass them. I understand we will pass then en bloc and before we do that, we should adopt the, I believe, en bloc amendment to H.R. 2061, which includes the amendment from Mr. Connolly.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> With that, unless someone wants me to yield time, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Yoho"> Members seeking recognition will be recognized for brief remarks. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Chabot</speaker> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Chabot"> </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Chabot</speaker> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Chabot">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Chabot">I want to thank the chairman for bringing this legislation before the subcommittee today. I rise in support of H.R. 535, the Taiwan Travel Act, a bill that I, along with my colleague and friend from California, Mr. Sherman, introduced earlier this year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Chabot">As a founding member of the Congressional Taiwan Caucus, I take the commitments of our country with Taiwan very seriously. Yesterday, I expressed my concerns to the Secretary of State, Tillerson, regarding our own self-imposed restrictions that prohibit high-ranking United States officials from meeting with their Taiwanese counterparts and, worse, bars Taiwanese officials from setting foot in our Nation's capital, in this city right here. It is ridiculous. This is a center of democracy and freedom. Taiwanese officials should be able to come and meet with American officials here in Washington, DC.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Chabot">This policy goes against our own self-interest. It tells China that we are willing to yield to them on our own foreign policy. It conveys weakness, I believe, to Beijing. Not only does restricting visits by high-level Taiwanese decision-makers tie our leaders' hands and insult an ally, it makes it nearly impossible to conduct diplomacy in an increasingly critical region.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Chabot">The United States should have direct dialogue with the democratically-elected leadership of Taiwan and it is time to change this outdated policy. The Taiwan Travel Act will do this.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Chabot">China continues to take aggressive actions that further its long-running campaign to isolate Taiwan. The United States has a legal and moral commitment to defend Taiwan sovereignty in the face of these attacks. Restricting high-level visits from Taiwan insults and ally and damages our national security in an increasingly dangerous world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Chabot">The United States should encourage direct dialogue with the democratically-elected leadership of our ally, Taiwan. It is time to change our policy. I encourage my colleagues to support this measure.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Chabot"> I once again want to thank Mr. Sherman for his leadership on this issue as well, making it a bipartisan measure. And I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Thank you, Mr. Chabot.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Next we will go to Ms. Gabbard. Did you have a comment?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Mrs. Wagner.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Mrs. Wagner. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Yoho">I would like to express my support for all of today's initiatives, including the Taiwan Travel Act, which I believe can be, frankly, the cornerstone for a more what I will call a mature relationship with Taiwan that recognizes Taiwan's tremendous contributions to both democracy and to stability in the Asia Pacific.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Yoho">I would also like to speak specifically in support of House Resolution 311, the resolution I was honored to introduce with my colleague, Representative Castro, in commemoration of ASEAN's 50th anniversary and the 40th anniversary of U.S.-ASEAN relations.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Southeast Asia has tremendous cultural, political, historical, and religious diversity. ASEAN was formed, in part, to create a bulwark against communism in the Southeast Asia among these diverse nations. And today, ASEAN's goals have evolved and the region is experiencing tremendous growth, nearly $100 billion in U.S. goods and services are exported to ASEAN, rivaling our $113 billion market in China.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Yoho">In January, I founded the bipartisan Congressional Caucus on ASEAN with my colleague, Congressman Castro. The Caucus acknowledges America's special relationship with ASEAN and defines ways that Congress can strengthen security, economic, technical, and humanitarian engagement in Southeast Asia.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Yoho">House Resolution 311 was one of our first initiatives and I am grateful that the chair and the ranking member are strong supporters of this effort. The resolution supports and affirms the elevation of the United States-ASEAN relationship to a strategic partnership and reaffirms a U.S. commitment to promoting a rules-based order in the Asia Pacific and economic growth, peace, human rights, and stability in Southeast Asia.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Yoho"> With that, Mr. Chairman, I yield back. Thank you. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Thank you, Mrs. Wagner for those great remarks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Hearing no further request for recognition, the question occurs on the items considered en bloc.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Yoho"> All those in favor, say aye. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> Mr. Chairman, we amended H.R. 2061 with the two en bloc amendments as part of this? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Yoho"> Yes, sir. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> Okay, so it includes both adopting the en bloc amendment to 2061 and your motion also passes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Yoho"> Yes, sir, and I thank you for pointing that out. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Sherman">That makes it an outstanding motion, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Oh, we may have one more.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> [Simultaneous speaking.] </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Yoho"> We have the honor of being joined by Ms. Ros- Lehtinen. Do you have a comment that you would like to---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Sherman">And I do want to remark I am thrilled that the left wing of this table has become so popular.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> Mrs. Wagner. Solidarity! Solidarity! </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sherman</speaker> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Sherman">We are just moderating that side.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Ms. Ros-Lehtinen. Now that FOX has let go of its fair and balanced slogan.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Thank you, Dr. Yoho, and thank you, Ranking Member Sherman. We have our own subcommittee hearing on Russia and the Middle East downstairs, so I am a little out of breath. But thank you for working with our office to bring the North Korea Human Right Reauthorization Act of 2017 to markup today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Sherman">I was proud to author and lead the reauthorization of this important law in both 2008 and 2012, and I am proud to do so again with the measure before you today, H.R. 2061.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Since 2004, the Human Rights Act of North Korea has provided us in the United States with a number of essential tools, designed to promote North Korean human rights. H.R. 2061 ensures that those tools will continue to be available, including authorizing grants that promote human rights, democracy and the rule of law; authorizing actions aimed at promoting the freedom of information, including increasing the availability of information sources not controlled by the Kim regime; authorizing humanitarian assistance to North Korean refugees, defectors, migrants, and orphans, as well as women who are victims of trafficking. It also ensures that the Special Envoy for North Korea Human Rights Issues; once someone is re-appointed, as is required by the original law, continues reporting to Congress on how he or she is fulfilling their responsibilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Every day under the Kim regime, North Koreans are suffering unimaginable horrors. They live under constant fear of arrest, of disappearance, of execution. They are exploited. They are trafficked, while dissidents are starved and tortured. Rule of law, justice, and freedom of expression simply do not exist.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Mr. Sherman">With this bill, we ensure that our efforts in the United States to promote North Korean human rights continue, that desperately needed information is getting to those inside, and that refugees fleeing the regime are receiving protection.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Mr. Sherman">Before I go, I would like to express my support for Chairman Yoho's Distribution and Promotion of Rights and Knowledge Act, which makes some very valuable additions to the North Korea Human Rights Act, including promoting additional methods of electronic communication and authorizing the broadcast of popular culture, as well as knowledge about the rights, the laws, the freedoms which North Koreans should be afforded.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Mr. Sherman">The Kim regime cannot be allowed to maintain its monopoly on information and we must continue to explore every possible avenue in order to allow North Koreans to get the information they need.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Mr. Sherman"> I thank the chair. I thank the ranking member and all the members for allowing me to join you today. And I yield back. Thank you, sir. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Thank you, Ms. Ros-Lehtinen. Everybody wants to know why you stay so fit and it is because you run from one committee hearing to the next.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Ms. Ros-Lehtinen. From one meal to the next.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Mr. Yoho"> Voice. And I am coming to the next, too. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Yoho</speaker> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Hearing no further requests for recognition, the question occurs on the items considered en bloc, along with the approval of the amendments.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Mr. Yoho">All those in favor say aye.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="63" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Opposed?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="64" speaker="Mr. Yoho">In the opinion of the Chair, the ayes have it and the measures considered en bloc are agreed to. Without objection, the measures considered en bloc are ordered favorably reported to the full committee, as amended, and staff is directed to make any technical and conforming changes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="65" speaker="Mr. Yoho">That concludes our markup.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="66" speaker="Mr. Yoho">[Whereupon, at 2:48 p.m., the subcommittee was adjourned.]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="67" speaker="Mr. Yoho">----------</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="68" speaker="Mr. Yoho">Material Submitted for the Record</paragraph>
